thread.title: 100 years since the House of Windsor got its name - but how did it happen?

author: Harry Mount
title: 100 years since the House of Windsor got its name - but how did it happen?

organizations.name: queen mary credit: w. & d. downey/getty images harry mount

text:
Family 100 years since the House of Windsor got its name - but how did it happen? King George VI, Prince Albert, Prince George, Duke of Kent, Queen Mary, Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester, King George V, (1865 - 1936), and Countess of Harewood, Mary, Princess Royal celebrating the Silver Wedding Anniversary of King George and Queen Mary Credit: W. & D. Downey/Getty Images Harry Mount 21 February 2017 • 2:42pm 
I f history had gone a little differently, it wouldn’t be Elizabeth Windsor who has just celebrated 65 years on the throne – but Elizabeth Tudor, Elizabeth Stuart or even Elizabeth Plantagenet. 
All those ancient, dynastic names were considered a century ago as replacements for George V’s real surname – Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, given to the royal family by Prince Albert when he married Queen Victoria . 
In 1917, anti-German feeling was so bad that, Graham Greene said, dachshunds were kicked on the streets of his native Berkhamsted, in Hertfordshire; it is that sentiment that is explored in a new Channel 4 series, The Royal House of Windsor. Prince William's christening in 1982 Credit: Fox Photos/Getty Images 
D uring the First World War, the royal family were doubly damned. Not only did they have a German surname, and buckets of German blood flowing through their veins. But also the bombs raining down on London were dropped by planes with the distinctly embarrassing name...
